verses.text: And they set out from Elim, and all the congregation of the sons of Israel came to the Wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after they had departed from the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: The Wilderness of Sin is not related to the English word 'sin,' but is a location name. This marks the first full month of Israel's journey in the wilderness.

verses.text: And the whole congregation of the sons of Israel grumbled against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
verses.comment: This pattern of grumbling highlights Israel's recurring doubts and lack of faith, despite God's mighty acts.

verses.text: And the sons of Israel said to them, 'Would that we had died by the hand of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the pots of meat and ate bread to the full! For you have brought us out into this wilderness to kill this whole assembly with hunger.'
verses.comment: This verse shows Israel's tendency to romanticize the past, even in slavery, when faced with hardship.

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, 'Behold, I will rain bread from heaven for you, and the people shall go out and gather a day's portion every day, so that I may test them, whether or not they will walk in My law.'
verses.comment: God introduces the manna as both provision and test. This has spiritual significance; Jesus refers to Himself as the true bread from heaven (John 6:32-35), prefiguring the Eucharistic themes found in Christian worship.

verses.text: And on the sixth day, when they prepare what they bring in, it will be twice as much as they gather daily.'
verses.comment: Here the Sabbath is foreshadowed as a day apart, requiring preparation the day before—hinting at the sacredness and structure of weekly worship.

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the sons of Israel, 'At evening you shall know that the Lord has brought you out from the land of Egypt,'
verses.comment: The Lord's deliverance is to be recognized not only in the past event of the Exodus but continually through His ongoing provision.

verses.text: And in the morning, you will see the glory of the Lord, because He has heard your murmurings against the Lord. What are we, that you grumble against us?'
verses.comment: Moses reminds them that their complaints are ultimately against God Himself, not merely human leaders.

verses.text: And Moses said, 'When the Lord gives you meat to eat in the evening and bread in the morning to the full, because the Lord has heard your grumblings which you grumble against Him—what are we? Your murmurings are not against us, but against the Lord.'
verses.comment: Moses assures the people that God is attentive to their needs but underscores the seriousness of complaining against God. This is a lesson in obedience and reverence.

verses.text: Then Moses said to Aaron, 'Say to all the congregation of the sons of Israel, “Come near before the Lord, for He has heard your murmurings.”'
verses.comment: An invitation to draw near to God’s presence; approaching Him is a central aspect of communal worship and covenant relationship.

verses.text: And it came to pass, as Aaron spoke to the whole congregation of the sons of Israel, that they looked toward the wilderness, and behold, the glory of the Lord appeared in the cloud.
verses.comment: God's visible presence signifies His closeness and guidance—a theme fulfilled in the New Testament where the glory of God is revealed in Christ (John 1:14).

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: A new divine instruction follows in response to the people's need and grumbling.

verses.text: 'I have heard the grumblings of the sons of Israel. Speak to them, saying, “At twilight you shall eat meat, and in the morning you shall be filled with bread; and you shall know that I am the Lord your God.”'
verses.comment: God answers their need, not only providing sustenance but deepening the covenant by self-revelation.

verses.text: So it came to pass in the evening that quail came up and covered the camp, and in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
verses.comment: Miraculous quail and manna show God's providential care. The dew signals the coming of manna—God's presence is often revealed in subtle and tangible ways.

verses.text: And when the layer of dew evaporated, behold, on the surface of the wilderness was a fine flake-like thing, fine as frost on the ground.
verses.comment: The description emphasizes the miraculous nature and foreignness of manna.

verses.text: And when the sons of Israel saw it, they said to one another, 'What is it?' For they did not know what it was. And Moses said to them, 'This is the bread which the Lord has given you to eat.'
verses.comment: The word 'manna' is from their question ('What is it?'). This 'bread from heaven' points toward the heavenly bread Jesus later promises—its fullness arriving in the New Testament.

verses.text: 'This is what the Lord has commanded: "Gather of it, every man as much as he should eat; you shall take an omer apiece according to the number of persons each of you has in his tent."'
verses.comment: God provides enough for each family's need, foreshadowing the principle of sufficiency and trust in God’s provision.

verses.text: The sons of Israel did so, and some gathered much and some little.
verses.comment: Obedience to God's instruction begins, but as the next verses show, obedience is tested.

verses.text: But when they measured it with an omer, he who had gathered much had nothing left over, and he who had gathered little had no lack; each gathered just as much as he should eat.
verses.comment: Paul quotes this in 2 Corinthians to illustrate Christian sharing and equality. God’s provision meets every need perfectly.

verses.text: And Moses said to them, 'Let no one leave any of it until morning.'
verses.comment: Storing manna would show a lack of trust in daily provision; echoes 'Give us this day our daily bread' (Matt. 6:11).

verses.text: But they did not listen to Moses; some left part of it until morning, and it bred worms and stank. And Moses was angry with them.
verses.comment: Lack of faith leads to consequences. God wants trust and obedience, not hoarding.

verses.text: So they gathered it every morning, each as much as he should eat. And when the sun grew hot, it melted.
verses.comment: God’s provision requires daily effort and reliance, another connection to seeking God's presence and grace daily.

verses.text: And it came to pass on the sixth day, they gathered twice as much bread, two omers for each. And all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses.
verses.comment: God sanctifies the seventh day by preparing His people for it, anticipating the importance of rest and worship.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'This is what the Lord has spoken: “Tomorrow is a day of rest, a holy Sabbath to the Lord. Bake what you will bake and boil what you will boil, and all that remains over lay by to keep until morning.”'
verses.comment: Sabbath is distinguished as holy, set apart for rest and spiritual focus—setting a precedent for structured weekly worship and sacred time.

verses.text: So they laid it aside until the morning, as Moses commanded, and it did not stink, nor were there any worms in it.
verses.comment: Obedience preserves God’s blessing. The miracle supports the unique sanctity of the Sabbath.

verses.text: And Moses said, 'Eat that today, for today is a Sabbath to the Lord; today you will not find it in the field.'
verses.comment: God commands a day of worshipful rest. The Sabbath principle is foundational for communal spiritual life and liturgy.

verses.text: Six days you shall gather it, but on the seventh day, which is the Sabbath, there will be none.
verses.comment: A clear rhythm of work and sacred rest is established, which later shapes the Christian understanding of worship and holy days.

verses.text: Yet it came to pass on the seventh day that some of the people went out to gather, but they found none.
verses.comment: Some still lack trust, demonstrating the need for discipline and faithfulness regarding sacred commands.

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, 'How long do you refuse to keep My commandments and My laws?'
verses.comment: God emphasizes obedience as central to covenant life—obedience is faith in action.

verses.text: 'See, for the Lord has given you the Sabbath; therefore He gives you on the sixth day the bread of two days. Let every man stay in his place; let no man go out of his place on the seventh day.'
verses.comment: The Sabbath is presented as a divine gift—not merely a rule, but an act of grace and provision, fostering a spirit of worship and unity.

verses.text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
verses.comment: Rest was a communal act, not individual. The pattern of communal worship and rest foreshadows the Christian celebration of sacred time together.

verses.text: And the house of Israel called its name manna. It was like coriander seed, white, and its taste was like wafers made with honey.
verses.comment: Manna is described as sweet—pointing spiritually to God's gracious provision, later echoed in the goodness of divine promises fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: And Moses said, 'This is what the Lord has commanded: “Let an omer of it be kept throughout your generations so that they may see the bread with which I fed you in the wilderness when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.”'
verses.comment: God commands memory and tradition: the manna is kept as a perpetual witness. Such memorials inspire faithfulness across generations, anticipating sacramental remembrance in Christian life.

verses.text: And Moses said to Aaron, 'Take a jar, and put an omer full of manna in it, and lay it up before the Lord to be kept throughout your generations.'
verses.comment: Physical memorials are instituted: an ongoing sign of God’s faithfulness. Ancient Christian worship retained such tangible memorial practices.

verses.text: As the Lord commanded Moses, so Aaron laid it up before the Testimony, to be kept.
verses.comment: The manna placed before the Testimony points to the significance of sacred symbols and lasting witness in the life of faith.

verses.text: The sons of Israel ate the manna forty years, until they came to a settled land; they ate the manna until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
verses.comment: Manna is God's daily provision through the entire wilderness—a symbol of continual, sustaining grace until God's people reach their promised rest.

verses.text: Now an omer is a tenth of an ephah.
verses.comment: This provides clarity about the measurement, showing attention to careful tradition and preserving precise details for worship.
